awd_titl_txt: RI: Medium: Computation, Language, and Games
awd_abstract_narration:
While game theory has been able to make useful predictions in many situations of interest, it is well known that, in many games of interest, the predictions of game theory are simply incorrect. This project focuses on one potential explanation: players' computational limitations. Game theory has assumed that all players are rational. In the literature, "rational" is taken to mean, among other things, that players can compute their beliefs and a best response to what they believe other players are doing. But such computations may not be so easy to perform. The project will still assume that players are rational, but will try to model explicitly the fact that people are computationally bounded and are affected by how games are framed/described in terms of language. It will then consider the consequences of assuming that people are playing rationally in the sense of doing the best that they can, subject to their computational limitations and how they describe their world. 

More specifically, the project will focus on three inter-related topics.  1) Taking computation into account in human behavior: The project will investigate how the formal models introduced in the PI's earlier work on games with computationally bounded players can be used to explain human behavior such as rational inattention, where people seem to ignore variables that seem relevant, and anomalies in human behavior in real-world deployments of game theory to applications such as security of wildlife and fisheries, forest protection, and drug interdiction. 2) Computational and language issues in dynamic games: Intuitively, as an agent does computation, his understanding of the game improves, his judgments of uncertainty becomes sharper, he may become aware of more options, and his utility function may change. The project will investigate approaches to modeling this process, including issues such as procrastination effects ("I'd rather start my diet tomorrow and eat the chocolate cake today than start my diet today"; if this reasoning is applied every day, the agent will never start his diet). 3) Cryptography and game theory: Modern cryptography can usefully be viewed as a game between resource-bounded agents. The project will investigate these connections, with the hope of being able to design better cryptographic protocols. One concrete outcome of the work will be better mechanisms for achieving desired outcomes. For example, understanding the effect of computational limitations on people's behavior may enable better mechanisms for preventing poaching. A particular focus area will be Bitcoin, which can be viewed as a game between resource-bounded miners.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the implications of adding computational cost to game theory, and more generally, studied more realistic models of rationality. The focus was on three inter-related topics:


(A) Taking computation into account in human behavior: Leveraging our earlier work, we investigated new models of rationality, and use them to explain human behavior. Specifically, we considered the following:


(1) How people decide what to focus on: Our techniques give insight into two apparently unrelated, but well-studied problems: (a) rational inattention, that is, when it is rational to ignore pertinent information (the optimal strategy for deciding if a statement p is true may involve hardly ever testing variables that are clearly relevant to p) and (b) what makes a formula hard to learn/remember?


(2) How computationally limited agents modeled probabilistic finite automata (PFAs) deal with Stackelberg games (which have been used to model applications like poaching behavior, forest protection, and drug interdiction) and multi-armed bandits (a classic tool for modeling theinteraction between exploration and exploitation in many real-world problems).  Our results show that as the number of states in the PFA decreases, PFA that solve these problems optimally exhibit more and more "human-like" behavior.  Specifically, they exhibit negativity bias (negative outcomes have a greater effect than positive ones), satisficing behavior (accepting outcomes that give rewards above a certain threshold, rather than trying to optimize rewards),and probability matching (in the case of poaches, visiting sites in proportion to the probability of a rhino being there).  Indeed, adding such human-like behavior can actually improve performance. These enable us to better understand human behavior and to design better mechanisms to encourage desirable behavior.


(3) What are appropriate solution concepts in games where utilities and probabilities are expressed coarsely (e.g. using terms like "very likely" and "unlikely", rather than using numerical probabilities or utilities).  Notions like the endowment effect (the observation that people are more likely to value an object they own higher than the same object when they do not own it) fall naturally out of these solution concepts.

(B) Implementing mediators: In many cases, a mediator can help non-cooperative (and possibly resource-bounded) agents obtain an equilibrium that may otherwise not be possible.  We study the ability of players to obtain the same equilibrium without a mediator, using only cheap talk, that is, nonbinding pre-play communication.   We consider this problem in the context of asynchronous games and for sequential equilibrium (a well-studied solution concept that is arguably more appropriate than Nash equilibrium in dynamic games, that evolve over time), proving results that significantly improve previous results and proving matching lower bounds.  This work should improve the ability to implement outcomes in real systems.


(C) Connections to Cryptography: Modern cryptography can usefully be viewed as a game between resource-bounded agents. We explored and developed these connections. Most notably, by designing new game-based ways to think about cryptography, developing new secure computation protocols (which in turn can be used to implement mediators), and by developing new connections between Cryptography and the Kolmogorov complexity: in particular, proving the equivalence of the existence of one-way functions (a long-standing open problem in cryptography) and the difficulty of, roughly speaking, computing Kolmogorov complexity (a standard approach to measuring the complexity of a string of symbols).


These results deepen our theoretical understanding on the connections between game theory, language, computation difficulty, and cryptography, thus having impact well beyond core computer science; and have practical implications in terms of helping us design better mechanisms.
